messageBody:
Hi,

I've run into a bit of a problem in trying to understand how to
implement the solution in the JUnit FAQ for having one time setUp
and tearDown.
In my JUnit setup, I have a class called TestSuiteMain whose main
() method looks something like:

public static void main(String[] args)
{
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
suite.addTest(new TestSuite(TestLookup.class));
suite.addTest(new TestSuite(TestDBMaps.class));

junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite);
}

In the TestDBMaps class, I have a setUp() method that loads a
database with data, and a tearDown() method that purges the
database. There are 30+ test methods that query the database, for
each specific data mapping, strings the results together, and uses
and assert to compare to the solution string. I only want the
database to be loaded once before the tests and purged once after
the tests.

In my TestDBMaps class (which extends TestCase), I tried the
solution given in the FAQ. So, I added:

public static Test suite()
{
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();

TestSetup wrapper = new TestSetup(suite)
{
protected void setUp()
{
oneTimeSetUp();
}

protected void tearDown()
{
oneTimeTearDown();
}
};
return wrapper;
}

I renamed my original setUp() and tearDown() to oneTimeSetUp() and
oneTimeTearDown() and made them static.

The problem now is that the TestDBMaps.suite() method does not
execute. I assume I've put this in the wrong spot, however, I'm not
sure where to put it... again I'm assuming my TestSuiteMain class.
If so, do I need to get rid of the TestSuiteMain.main() and replace
it with TestSuiteMain.suite()?

I really do not want to place the logic for one time setup and
teardown in my TestSuiteMain since the setup for one of the test
classes is very different than it is for another test class. To
place the logic in my TestSuiteMain would then require me to make a
monolithic set up and tear down that handles all classes... and this
will only grow as I add more test classes to my package.

What is the best way to handle what I'm trying to accomplish?

On another note, I found the JUnit documentation on www.junit.org to
be a little hard to understand, personally. And it didn't seem to
go quite into as much depth as I would like. Can anyone recommend a
good book on the subject? One that covers XUnit methodologies in
other languages would be great too.

Thank you,
Curt
